Thanks, :jake: says great things.
Also you can find some inspections in IDEA / Android Studio from J2ME, Preformance and Memory groups that help in finding such things out.
Where did J2ME come into this?
There are some inspections called "J2ME issues" in IDEA that stand for kinds of optimizations in memory- and CPU-constrained environments.

Does anyone know an article or something else that explains how to use RxJava with Realm? The limitations and such. Their blog post from 1.5 years ago is outdated it seems.
I'm wondering about the usage findAllAsync() together with asObservable() and how it interacts with subscribeOn() and observerOn() knowing Realm doesn't support cross threaded objects.
Like what are its limits and boundaries?

If only Realm had a non-Japanese Slack or IRC. The only response I got was that they think StackOverflow is enough. But I don't want to get screamed at by SO elitists that mark everything as a duplicate, but that's a completely different rant.
Ah got it: <https://github.com/realm/realm-java/tree/master/examples/rxJavaExample>

attachments.title: realm/realm-java
attachments.text: realm-java - Realm is a mobile database: a replacement for SQLite & ORMs

text: > Use the Realm async API instead of subscribeOn to move Realm work off the UI thread.
<@U061HDV96|andreasbackx> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/andreasbackx/F2PHLJB34/rxjava_first.kt|RxJava first>

file.name: RxJava_first.kt
file.title: RxJava first
file.preview_highlight:
realm.where(Store::class.java).findAllAsync().asObservable()
			.first { stores -> stores.isLoaded }
			.flatMap { stores -> Observable.from(stores) }

text: So Realm for some reason returns the list of stores twice (first why?) so I try to filter on that by only getting the first one that is loaded (ready for use) and then I want to make an observable that returns all of those individually. But the problem is that flatMap is called even if it's not the first one that is ready for use or loaded. Am I missing something?
Oh RxJava also has distinct()...
That solves it, but I would still want an explanation for my question above ^ :slightly_smiling_face:
Can't have code run for nothing
